explanation:
To find x-intercepts for \( y=(x-3)(x-5) \), set \( y=0 \):
\[
0=(x-3)(x-5) \implies x=3 \ \text{or} \ x=5 \Rightarrow \text{intercepts at } (3,0) \ \text{and} \ (5,0).
\]
The student incorrectly wrote \( (3,5) \), merging the roots \( 3 \) and \( 5 \) into a single coordinate pair. This suggests they treated the roots as both coordinates of one point rather than distinct \( x \)-values paired with \( y=0 \). Specifically, they failed to recognize that \( y=0 \) at all \( x \)-intercepts, leading them to conflate the two \( x \)-values into a single non-intercept point. 

This aligns with misunderstanding how coordinates define points on axes: the student did not associate each root with a separate intercept where \( y=0 \). It differs from misconceptions like reversing sign errors (e.g., writing \( (-3,0) \)) or assuming equal coordinates (e.g., \( (3,3) \)), as the error uniquely stems from misassigning the roots to both coordinates.
